annotation.name: OLiA
annotation.documentation:
OLiA Annotation Model for Penn Treebank (PTB) part-of-speech annotation (Santorini 1990)
Unless specified otherwise, all comments are taken from Santorini (1990).
References Beatrice Santorini (1990), Part-of-Speech tagging guidelines for the Penn Treebank Project, 3rd revision, 2nd printing, ftp://ftp.cis.upenn.edu/pub/treebank/doc/tagguide.ps.gz

concept.name: Adjective
concept.documentation: These are adjectives, ordinal numerals, and ordinal numbers. Hyphenated compounds that are used as modifiers are tagged as adjectives, e.g. "happy-go-lucky", "one-of-a-kind", "run-of-the-mill". Ordinal numbers are tagged as adjectives, as are compounds of the form "n-th" or "X-est", like "fourth-largest".

concept.name: Adverb
concept.documentation: This category includes most words that end in -ly as well as degree words like "quite", "too" and "very", posthead modifiers like "enough" and "indeed" (as in "good enough", "very well indeed"), and negative markers like "not", "n' t" and "never".

concept.name: BaseForm
concept.documentation: This tag subsumes imperatives, infinitives and subjunctives. EXAMPLES: Imperative: Do/VB it. Infinitive: You should do/VB it. We want them to do/VB it. We made them do/VB it. Subjunctive: We suggested that he do/VB it.

concept.name: BePastTense
concept.documentation: This category includes the conditional form of the verb to be. EXAMPLES: If I were/VBD rich... If I were/VBD to win the lottery...

concept.name: BePresentTense
concept.documentation: These are verbforms in present tense. This class includes 3rd person singular or other than 3rd person singular verbforms.

concept.name: CardinalNumber
concept.documentation: These are cardinal numbers.

concept.name: CommonNoun
concept.documentation: These are common nouns in singular or plural, or mass nouns.

concept.name: ComparativeAdjective
concept.documentation: These are adjectives mostly with the comparative ending -er and a comparative meaning. "More" or "less" should be tagged as a comparative adjective when it is used without a head noun and it corresponds to the object of a verb or preposition.

concept.name: ComparativeAdverb
concept.documentation: These are comparative adverbs.

concept.name: CoordinatingConjunction
concept.documentation: This category includes "and", "but", "nor", "or", "yet" (as in "Yet it's cheap", "cheap yet good"), as well as the mathematical operators "plus", "minus", "less", "times" (in the sense of "multiplied by") and "over" (in the sense of "divided by"), when they are spelled out. For in the sense of "because" is a coordinating conjunction.

concept.name: Determiner
concept.documentation: This category includes the articles "a(n)", "every", "no" and "the", the indefinite determiners "another", "any" and "some", "each", "either" (as in "either way"), "neither" (as in "neither decision"), "that", "these", "this" and "those", and instances of "all" and "both" when they do not precede a determiner or possessive pronoun (as in "all roads" or "both times").

concept.name: ExistentialThere
concept.documentation: Existential "there" is the unstressed "there" that triggers inversion of the inflected verb and the logical subject of a sentence, e.g. "There/EX was a party in progress.", "There/EX ensued a melee.".

concept.name: ForeignWord
concept.documentation: These are foreign words.

concept.name: GerundOrPresentParticiple
concept.documentation: This is a verb in present participle or in gerund.

concept.name: Interjection
concept.documentation: This category includes "my" (as in "My, what a gorgeous day"), "oh", "please", "see" (as in "See it's like this"), "uh", "well" and "yes", among others.

concept.name: ListItemMarker
concept.documentation: This category includes letters and numerals when they are used to identify items in a list.

concept.name: ModalVerb
concept.documentation: This category includes all verbs that don't take an -s ending in the third person singular present: "can", "could", ("dare"), "may", "might", "must", "ought", "shall", "should", "will", "would".

concept.name: Noun
concept.documentation: This is a class, we inserted to structure the tagset.

concept.name: Particle
concept.documentation: This category includes a number of mostly monosyllabic words that also double as directional adverbs and prepositions.

concept.name: PastParticiple
concept.documentation: This is a verb in past participle.

concept.name: PersonalPronoun
concept.documentation: This category includes the personal pronouns proper, without regard for case distinctions ("I", "me", "you", "he", "him", etc.), the reflexive pronouns ending in -self or -selves, and the nominal possessive pronouns "mine", "yours", "his", "hers", "ours" and "theirs".

concept.name: PossessiveEnding
concept.documentation: The possessive ending on nouns ending in 's or is split off by the tagging algorithm and tagged as if it were a separate word. e.g. "John/ NP 's/POS idea", "the parents/NNS'/POS distress".

concept.name: PossessivePronoun
concept.documentation: This category includes the adjectival possessive forms "my", "your", "his", "her", "its", "one's", "our" and "their".

concept.name: Predeterminer
concept.documentation: This category includes the following determinerlike elements when they precede an article or possessive pronoun. EXAMPLES: all/PDT his marbles nary/PDT a soul both/PDT the girls quite/PDT a mess half/PDT his time rather/PDT a nuisance many/PDT a moon such/PDT a good time

concept.name: PrepositionOrSubordinatingConjunction
concept.documentation: We make no explicit distinction between prepositions and subordinating conjunctions. (The distinction is not lost, however - a preposition is an IN that precedes a noun phrase or a prepositional phrase, and a subordinate conjunction is an IN that precedes a clause). The preposition "to" has its own special tag TO.

concept.name: Pronoun
concept.documentation: This is a class, we inserted to structure the tagset.

concept.name: ProperNoun
concept.documentation: These are singular or plural proper nouns.

concept.name: SuperlativeAdjective
concept.documentation: These are adjectives with the superlative ending -est (as well as "worst"). "Most" and "least" can also be tagged as superlative adjective when they occur by themselves.

concept.name: SuperlativeAdverb
concept.documentation: These are superlative adverbs.

concept.name: Symbol
concept.documentation: This tag should be used for mathematical, scientific and technical symbols or expressions that aren't words of English. It should not used for any and all technical expressions. For instance, the names of chemicals, units of measurements (including abbreviations thereof) and the like should be tagged as nouns.

concept.name: To
concept.documentation: "To" is tagged TO, regardless of whether it is a preposition or an infinitival marker.

concept.name: WhAdverb
concept.documentation: This category includes "how", "where", "why", etc. When in a temporal sense is tagged as wh-adverb. In the sense of "if", on the other hand, it is a subordinating conjunction. EXAMPLES: "When/WRB he finally arrived, I was on my way out."

concept.name: WhDeterminer
concept.documentation: This category includes "which", as well as that when it is used as a relative pronoun.

concept.name: WhPronoun
concept.documentation: This category includes "what", "who" and "whom".
